summary: This document is an email chain from February 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) staff discussing FOIA and Touhy requests related to Jeffrey Epstein. It concerns coordination between civil and criminal divisions on handling requests from plaintiffs/victims and media (specifically the New York Times) for government records, and includes draft legal language explaining the Touhy regulations governing such disclosures.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney at Kaplan & Hecker representing plaintiffs/victims in civil litigation related to Jeffrey Epstein; mentioned as the point of contact for a Touhy request.

events.title: Answer Date for NY Times FOIA Complaint
events.description: Deadline for the government's answer to the New York Times' FOIA complaint challenging the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) response to requests for Epstein-related records.

events.title: Discussion on Epstein-Related Touhy Requests
events.description: Internal discussion memorialized about designating a point person for handling Touhy requests from civil plaintiffs/victims in Epstein lawsuits, and planning to contact plaintiff's counsel.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA complaint challenging the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) response to requests for Jeffrey Epstein-related records, with a government answer date of March 4, 2020.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY was coordinating internally, with the civil division handling external communications for Touhy requests related to Epstein to maintain consistency and separate criminal prosecutors from direct contact with alleged victims who might also be witnesses.

Attorney Robbie Kaplan of Kaplan & Hecker is identified as counsel for plaintiffs/victims in civil litigation, and was to be contacted regarding the requirements for making a Touhy request for government materials.

The email includes extensive draft language explaining the Department of Justice's Touhy regulations, which govern the disclosure of information or testimony by government employees in litigation where the government is not a party, highlighting restrictions related to law enforcement investigations.
